title: Networking Basics
description: Foundational networking concepts and practical commands: OSI/TCP-IP models, Ethernet/IEEE 802, addressing, net/host IDs, subnetting, frames, handshakes, DHCP/DNS, common topologies, and troubleshooting.

categories.title: Models: OSI and TCP/IP
categories.description: How protocols map to layers and where troubleshooting usually starts.

items.title: OSI 7-layer model
items.example:
# Common triage flow
# L1: link up?
# L2: VLAN/MAC learning?
# L3: IP/gateway/routes?
# L4: ports/handshakes?
# L7: DNS/TLS/app errors?

items.title: OSI device mapping (ISO-style mental model)
items.description: Practical mapping of OSI layers to common network devices and functions.

items.title: TCP/IP model
items.description: A pragmatic 4-ish layer model that maps well to real stacks.

categories.title: IEEE 802 Quick Reference
categories.description: Common IEEE 802 standards you’ll see in switching and Wi‑Fi.

items.title: Most common 802.* standards
items.example: # VLAN tag has: PCP (802.1p), DEI, VLAN ID (802.1Q)

items.title: Ethernet vs Wi‑Fi basics
items.description: Ethernet is full-duplex point-to-point on switched networks; Wi‑Fi is shared medium with CSMA/CA.

categories.title: Ethernet/IP Frames and Packet Anatomy
categories.description: How data is encapsulated: Ethernet frame -> IP packet -> TCP/UDP segment.

items.title: Ethernet II frame fields (high level)
items.description: Ethernet II is the common framing on modern LANs.

rows: Where the frame is going on L2

items.example:
# Capture an Ethernet frame (Linux)
sudo tcpdump -e -nn -i eth0 -c 5

items.title: IPv4 header essentials (high level)
items.description: Enough to understand MTU/fragmentation, TTL, and routing behavior.

rows: Decrements each hop; prevents loops; used by traceroute

items.example:
# Inspect IPv4 fields
sudo tcpdump -nn -vv -i eth0 ip -c 5

items.title: TCP vs UDP (encapsulation)
items.example:
# Show TCP/UDP listeners
ss -tulpn

categories.title: Addressing Fundamentals
categories.description: MAC vs IP, private/public ranges, and classful vs CIDR concepts.

items.title: MAC vs IP vs Port
items.description: A common mental model: who (MAC), where (IP), which app (port).
items.example:
# Show MAC/IP on Linux
ip -br link
ip -br addr

items.title: IPv4 private ranges and special ranges
items.description: Know which addresses are private, loopback, link-local, multicast, etc.

items.description: Classful addressing is mostly historical, but still useful for learning net/host splits.
items.example:
# Example (Class C default): 192.168.1.0/24

categories.title: Subnetting and CIDR
categories.description: Calculate network, broadcast, and usable ranges. Understand prefixes, masks, and VLSM.

items.title: CIDR quick table
items.description: Common IPv4 prefixes and host counts.
items.example:
# Usable host count (typical IPv4): 2^(32-prefix) - 2
# (Except /31 point-to-point and /32 host routes)

items.title: Worked subnet example
items.example:
# Find /27 network: round down to nearest multiple of 32 in last octet
# 34 -> 32

items.title: NetID / HostID (CIDR way)
items.description: NetID is the prefix bits; HostID is the remaining bits.
items.example:
# On Linux, see kernel-computed routes that imply NetID
ip route

items.title: Handy tools
items.description: Commands that help you confirm subnet assumptions.

categories.title: ARP, ICMP, and Local Discovery
categories.description: How hosts find local neighbors and troubleshoot reachability.

items.title: ARP (IPv4) basics
items.description: ARP maps IPv4 -> MAC on the local LAN. ARP does not cross routers.

rows: Resolve L2 destination for an IPv4 next hop
Can’t reach local gateway; ARP incomplete

items.example:
ip neigh
arp -n

items.title: ICMP and ping
items.description: Ping uses ICMP Echo Request/Reply; it checks reachability but not application health.
items.example:
ping -c 3 1.1.1.1
traceroute -n 1.1.1.1

categories.title: TCP/UDP, Ports, and Handshakes
categories.description: How connections start and end; why ports and state matter.

items.title: TCP 3-way handshake
items.description: Connection establishment (simplified).

rows: Client requests connection; proposes initial sequence
Server accepts; proposes its own sequence

items.example:
# Observe a TCP handshake (requires traffic)
sudo tcpdump -nn -i eth0 'tcp[tcpflags] & (tcp-syn|tcp-ack) != 0'

items.title: TCP teardown
items.description: Graceful close uses FIN/ACK; RST indicates abort.
items.example:
# Show established connections
ss -tan state established

items.title: UDP basics
items.description: UDP has no handshake; apps may implement retries/timeouts.
items.example:
# UDP listeners
ss -uapn

items.title: TLS handshake (very high level)
items.description: TLS runs above TCP: negotiate cipher/version, authenticate server (cert), derive session keys.
items.example: openssl s_client -connect example.com:443 -servername example.com

categories.title: DHCP
categories.description: Automatic IP configuration (IPv4 common). Understand the DORA flow and key options.

items.title: DHCP DORA handshake
items.example:
# Capture DHCP (IPv4)
sudo tcpdump -nn -i eth0 'udp and (port 67 or port 68)'

items.title: Common DHCP options
items.description: Options define defaults: gateway, DNS, lease time, etc.

items.title: DHCP client commands (common)
items.description: Depends on OS and network stack.

rows: nmcli dev disconnect [iface]; nmcli dev connect [iface]

items.example: sudo dhclient -v eth0

categories.title: DNS
categories.description: Name to IP resolution and the tools to query it.

items.title: Core DNS record types
items.example:
dig example.com A
dig example.com AAAA
dig -x 8.8.8.8

items.title: DNS troubleshooting commands
items.description: Compare raw DNS answers (dig) vs application view (getent).
items.example:
dig +short example.com
getent hosts example.com

categories.title: Routing Basics
categories.description: Default gateway, routing tables, and the difference between local and routed traffic.

items.title: Key routing concepts

rows: Where traffic goes if no more specific route exists
Usually a router IP on your LAN
Routes created when an interface has an IP

items.example:

ip route

items.title: Route inspection commands
items.example: ip route get 8.8.8.8

categories.title: Basic Troubleshooting Toolkit
categories.description: Commands that solve most first-response networking issues.

items.title: Local configuration

rows: ip -br addr; ip route; resolvectl status; ss -tulpn

items.example:
ip -br addr
ip route

items.title: End-to-end checks
items.description: Start: IP reachability, then DNS, then TCP/HTTPS.
items.example:
ping -c 3 1.1.1.1
dig +short example.com
nc -vz example.com 443
curl -v https://example.com

items.title: Packet capture basics
items.description: When in doubt, capture traffic.

rows: sudo tcpdump -nn -i eth0 tcp port 443 and host [ip]

items.example: sudo tcpdump -nn -i eth0 'udp port 53'
